metadata.title: We need Synthetic Data. The benefits and methods of synthetic… | by Joseph Allen | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: Synthetic data is an upcoming technology in the data industry. There are many reasons to explore synthetic data, which I will go into shortly. A computer program manufactures synthetic data. We no…

all_paragraphs: Synthetic data is an upcoming technology in the data industry. There are many reasons to explore synthetic data, which I will go into shortly.
Sometimes the most effective way to collect more data is to make it yourself.

A computer program manufactures synthetic data. We no longer measure real-world events. There are many methods for generating synthetic data. These methods can range from find and replace, all the way up to modern machine learning. The synthesis starts easy, but complexity rises with the complexity of our data. To use synthetic data you need domain knowledge. You need to understand what personal data is, and dependence between features. Only with domain knowledge could you answer the following:

We can change our data in many ways to protect the anonymity of any individuals captured in a dataset. One method is replacing common personal details like emails, names and addresses. Depending on your dataset, your data may become less useful without accurate addresses. In this case, reducing granularity could be acceptable.
There has been an increase in black-box attacks on models to infer details of the training data. A model trained on synthetic data is less at risk.

Generating more data could be an effective way to improve the results of your model. In image data, you can improve your training set by performing some transformations. Shearing, shifting, rotating and all combinations of these can be useful. An ImageDataGenerator exists in Keras to handle this. An example of this applying to the MNIST dataset is available here.

If you want to detect fraudulent transactions you cannot buy more fraud cases. You may not have the luxury of waiting for more to occur. Using oversampling we can create more fraud cases. A more dangerous example might be collecting data on car crashes, or cancer scans. In some cases, waiting isn’t an option.

How would you collect a dataset of a thousand chess games? You could hire players, record games and convert moves into chess notation. You could pay for a larger dataset, or dedicate many hours to transcribing games yourself. The rules, notation and bots for chess are already known. Synthetic data, instead, might be the most cost and time-effective method here.

I consider accessibility to be the most important aspect of open data. If data can’t be accessed without filling out paperwork, signing EULA’s and more potential is limited. In the exploratory world of data, experts are often keen to make use of public data, for free. Let’s try our best not to block them.

If your synthetic data contains no sensitive data it can comfortably be shared outside of your organisation. Even sharing a handful of rows to show the structure of the data, alongside any documentation is a great step forward. We should be striving to make our data easier to access. Too many public datasets require a large investment into the unknown. Accessible data can be more easily reproduced and criticised by other experts.
Let’s take a look at the above data, we have:
We need domain knowledge to recognise how dangerous the ID column is. Does your organisation have data connected to this ID? If yes, we need to replace this. Let’s reindex these.

We could apply anonymisation to each column in isolation. That is generating a new and unconnected first_name, last_name, email, gender and address. A big problem in synthetic data is maintaining the distributions of a dataset. For example, should we have an email that makes use of the first and last name? Is it good enough to replace the address with a new address? If we need to know something about the address of an individual this might not be appropriate.

Instead, a better approach here would be to generate an email and other features using our fake data. For the user “Joe Bang” An email like Jbang@gmail.com might appear more genuine. We coarsen the address to maintain the general area, without identifying the individual.

Now again you must understand the context of this dataset. If for example there is only one individual in the postcode M3, we have not made them less anonymous. The same holds if there was only one female in our dataset. You must not skip the exploratory phase before making these decisions.
The data in government blog outlines the techniques used in data synthesis here. The following categorise these techniques.
Replacing parts of the dataset with randomly generated information. For example replacing real names, with names generated by the Faker Python library.
Here we have masked the last_name column.

Removing sensitive rows from the dataset. Often, outliers in a dataset are sensitive by being outliers. If you have a list of addresses, the address of military bases may need redaction. In a list of children in a school, one student may have a higher number of siblings by far. This alone can identify this student. In our fraudulent transaction case from earlier, removing outliers removes our target. Again context is key in this decision.

Anonymising the names, and adding to the number of siblings is not enough to protect Waring Mineghelli. In this case, it is more appropriate to redact Waring’s data altogether. If our business product is a number of siblings predictor then we can make a case to our data officer that we need this important outlier.
Coarsening is about reducing the precision of the data. For example, instead of listing a full name, store only the initials. For a postcode, we could store only the first two digits.
In this example, we have coarsened the first_name column. While this data is slightly more anonymous, depending on the dataset.
Generation of a dataset close to real data, but with added randomness. For example, here add or subtract a random amount to heights and weights.
In this example, we have mimicked the number of siblings by adding a random value from -1 to 1. As you can see this is not enough to protect our outlier.

The most difficult, but the most effective method is generating a new dataset. Using machine learning methods we can understand the relationships between features. We can then generate new rows that maintain these relationships. Now there is no need to obfuscate our individuals, as they no longer exist. Common methods here include GANs, VAEs and more.

While there are many data mocking libraries, that doesn’t mean you need to know how to code. Mockaroo allows you to generate 1000s of rows of structured data. You can generate 1000 rows at a time on the free tier. No programming required.

Data mocking involves generating realistic test cases. These are usually generated by libraries containing large sets of common values. These values could be names, emails, phone numbers, social security numbers and more. These standard values cover most use cases. Where they don’t often a combination of these values can.

One great library for this is Faker. Faker comes with some standard providers. On top of this Faker also supports community providers, so if what you need doesn’t exist you can make it for the next user. Faker also supports multiple locales.

Sometimes small adjustments to our data are enough to improve our dataset. We use the domain knowledge of this data to inform which adjustments are appropriate. In an image example of identifying cats or dogs, you may need to classify the following image.

You now have a dataset of size 1. This isn’t much to work with. Using data augmentation we can generate more data from this image. We do this by applying zooming, shearing, flipping, translating, rotating and more.

It’s not too much effort to make these. As we said before, an ImageDataGenerator exists in Keras to handle this. An example of this applying to the MNIST dataset is available here. An alternative library to look into here is Albumentations.
What if our dataset is text-based? Back translation is one example technique we could use. This involves translating from one language, into another and then back. This can be done in Google Sheets.

SMOTE stands for Synthetic Minority Over-Sampling Technique. To simplify that, in a problem where we are trying to predict a minority class such as our fraudulent transactions example. We might have a thousand transactions, with only ten labelled as fraudulent. SMOTE assumes that points on the lines connecting elements of this minority class are valid potential additions to the class. This post goes into more detail on SMOTE.
This credit card fraud exploration outlines a great application of SMOTE. The imblearn library has some documentation on the SMOTE algorithm here.

VAE stands for Variable Auto-Encoder. Often we want to generate new and random data. With VAEs you can alter the data you generate with intention. A VAE is a neural network consisting of an encoder and a decoder. The encoder reduces the number of dimensions from our input set, to a single value. The decoder converts this single value back to the original data format. What’s powerful about this is that it’s realistic to ask this model to generate an image that is 90% cat and 10% dog. You can also follow this image-based exploration here. An example implementation in Keras is available here.
Two Neural networks make up a Generative Adversarial Network, or a GAN.

These networks work in tandem. The generator works to trick the discriminator. Both networks enjoy the data generated by the other. Generally, the more data we have for each network the better the other performs. You could imagine a child drawing cats and dogs, as a critical adult corrects them. With this, we can build networks that given an input, create an output with the desired property. You may be familiar with some of the Google DeepDream paintings.

As a note GANs are temperamental. Data generated by two neural networks, feeding into one another, is asking to go awry. GANs are right on the cutting edge and need a high degree of surveillance. For a more technical guide check out Shweta Goyal’s brief introduction.

Synthetic data is vital in the world of open data. If we want experts who are willing to donate their time to solve public problems we need to make it easy. Synthetic data solves the need for paperwork and data accounting. We can also take some steps to lower the commitment needed in a data exploration phase. If you own some data that could be open here are my suggested next steps:

There are countless methods of data synthesis. We haven’t yet solved general-case data synthesis. This means that when you rise to this challenge you need domain knowledge of your dataset. It’s not yet safe to assume that columns don’t contain sensitive data. Make sure you understand the context so that the people who make use of your data don’t have to.
Thanks for reading and good luck. — Joe

Joe works for the UK Data Service who are pioneers in data curation and secure, long-term research access to social science data. The UK Data Service’s expertise continues to transform social science teaching and learning. Find out more on the UK Data Service website. Joe will be giving three webinars on Synthetic Data in January so follow me for more details.
Manchester based Data Scientist, Digital Artist, Front-End Dev
